I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment of up to $35,000,000 (in Indian rupee equivalent) in Shubham Housing Development 
Finance Company Limited (Shubham) for the Shubham Supporting Housing Finance in Semi- 
and Peri-Urban Areas Project in India. 
 
2.  The equity investment of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provides growth capital to 
Shubham to support the expansion of its operations to provide critically needed affordable 
housing finance and home equity loans, primarily to economically weaker sections (EWS) and 
low-income groups (LIG) in semi- and peri-urban areas.1 Under the investment, Shubham will 
implement measures under a gender action plan (GAP) to expand access to credit for women. 
 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
3.  Affordable housing. Limited housing supply adversely affects the living conditions of 
lower-income households, especially in large cities characterized by low building standards. The 
shortage of housing units in India is estimated at 18.7 million in urban areas and 43.7 million in 
rural areas.2 More than 90% of this deficit is projected to be in the lower-income segment. The 
Government of India launched the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY) initiative in 2015, with a 
target of building 20 million affordable homes for the urban poor by 2022.3 To date, about 11.3 
million homes have been sanctioned.4 Under the PMAY, the government offers interest rate 
subsidies of 3.0%–6.5%, depending on the loan amount and the income category of the borrower, 
and other measures to incentivize the supply of affordable housing. 
 
4.  Finance sector overview. Banks dominate the finance sector accounting for more than 
64% of financial system assets.5 Nonbank financial companies (NBFCs) accounted for about 20% 
of overall system credit in March 2020 and are funding segments that typically are underserved 
or not catered to by banks. 6 The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) had 9,484 NBFCs registered as of 
31 May 2021. Despite the size of the banking industry, poor access to financial services remains 
a key issue in India, with 20.1% of people unbanked.7 Access to credit is even more limited, with 
less than 6.6% of the population accessing credit via formal channels.8 
 
1  For the purposes of “affordable housing”, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) defines (i) an EWS household as having 
a family income of less than ₹0.3 million per annum and (ii) an LIG household as having a family income of ₹0.3 
million–₹0.6 million per annum, and (iii) a middle-income household as having a family income of ₹0.6 million–₹1.8 
million per annum. RBI. 2018. Affordable Housing in India. New Delhi. For this report and recommendation of the 
President, lower-income households refer to EWS and LIG households.

5.  Asset quality varies, with higher gross nonperforming assets (NPAs) for public sector 
banks at 9.7% as compared with 4.6% for private sector banks as of 30 September 2020. In part 
because of a loan moratorium extended by the RBI and the restructuring of certain accounts, 
asset quality improved, with gross NPAs for the banks decreasing from 9.3% in fiscal year (FY) 
2019 to 7.5% as of 30 September 2020.9 The gross NPAs of the NBFCs stabilized at 6.4% in 
FY2021 (FY2020: 6.3%), but the impact of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is yet to be fully 
reflected on their books. 
 
6.  Housing finance sector. Mortgage penetration remains low in India and was 11.2% as 
of 30 September 2020—much lower than in other emerging markets such as Malaysia (35.4%), 
People’s Republic of China (27.9%) and Thailand (23.9%).10 The total volume of housing credit 
outstanding in India (including home equity loans) was about ₹22.8 trillion at the end of FY2021.11 
Banks primarily provide home loans to salaried employees in urban areas. Regulated by the RBI, 
the 91 housing finance companies (HFCs) are solely mandated to fund housing, catering to both 
the prime and the affordable segments. HFCs are significant players in mortgage financing, but 
their share declined from 38.0% in FY2018 to 33.0% at the end of FY2021 because of the 
continued liquidity stress facing the sector, rising competition from banks (largely in the prime 
segment), and the COVID-19 pandemic.12 The asset quality among the HFCs deteriorated to 
2.9% in FY2021 from 2.4% in FY2020 and is expected to deteriorate further with the full impact 
of COVID-19 expected to be known by the end of FY2022. Nevertheless, the asset quality among 
HFCs continues to outperform both banks and NBFCs. 
 
7.  Underserved  home  loan  borrower  segments.  Lower-income  households  are 
particularly  constrained  in  obtaining  mortgages  because  of  (i)  undocumented  incomes,  (ii) 
inadequate property rights limiting its use as collateral, (iii) perceived higher credit risk, (iv) lack 
of proximity to a bank branch, and (v) high origination costs because of the relatively small loan 
sizes. As a result, such households typically fund their homes through savings, borrowings from 
family and friends, or loans from local moneylenders at usurious interest rates. 
 
8.  Women’s access to housing credit. Access to finance for women is also extremely low, 
with only 5.0% of women reported to have borrowed from a formal financial institution and only 
3.0% having an outstanding home loan.13  Further, lack of housing finance is a critical issue for 
women, impairing their ability to own an important asset and gain economic security compared to 
men.14 Despite a large market size for women’s housing loans in India (estimated at $32.3 
billion),15 women’s access to housing finance remains constrained by insufficient income and 
documentation, lack of property titles, limited financial literacy, and traditional gender norms. A 
2016 survey of land ownership in northern and eastern India indicated that women owned only 
3.6% of plots, men owned 85.9%, and the remaining 10.5% were untitled.16 Recognizing the 
issues related to low levels of women’s property ownership, several Indian states have provided

tax incentives for women holding property titles. The Government of India also introduced a credit-
linked subsidy scheme program to bring more women into the housing finance market by 
providing a subsidized interest rate on housing loans if a woman holds the title to a new property.17 
On the supply side, most financial institutions do not have gender-specific products or services 
targeting women and, given their limited understanding of this customer segment, most financial 
services providers do not recognize the business case in actively serving the women’s market.18 
 
9.  Rationale. To address the large market gap and improve access to housing finance, 
particularly for women and lower-income households, ADB has identified HFC partners that have 
demonstrated the ability to reach such households on a sustainable basis. While ADB has 
provided debt funding to HFCs in India,19 the project will be ADB’s first equity investment in an 
HFC that targets lower-income households primarily residing in the peripheries of larger cities and 
in Tier II and below cities.20 As of FY2021, about 75% of Shubham’s portfolio comprised of lower-
income households, 61% of clients had an informal income, and 90% of loans disbursed were to 
women as the primary or co-borrowers. Further, 18% were first-time borrowers from a formal 
financial institution. Shubham has had stable business growth led by experienced promoters and 
supported by a strong management team. It has demonstrated superior asset quality relative to 
its peers on loans originated after the 2016 demonetization, and its asset quality has largely 
remained stable during the COVID-19 pandemic. Through its 99 branches spread across 9 states, 
Shubham caters to underserved lower-income households and uses technology to provide an 
efficient and cost-effective origination, approval, and monitoring system. The project will support 
the growth of Shubham as it emerges from the pandemic, allowing it to deepen its presence in 
existing geographies, and further expand to more Tier II and below cities. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
10.  Overview. Shubham began operations in January 2011, offering housing loans and home 
equity loans, catering largely to the informal segment. As of FY2021, 60% of its portfolio was for 
home purchase; 14% for self-construction; 4% for home improvement; and 20% were home equity 
loans,  typically  for  business  purposes.  Almost  all  its  loans  are  secured  by  self-occupied 
residences and are typically the first home for the borrower. Under a pilot program, Shubham also 
provides construction loans to small builders for small and medium-sized residential construction, 
which account for 2% of its portfolio. Shubham’s portfolio is concentrated in Maharashtra (36%), 
followed by Uttar Pradesh and Delhi (14% each), Haryana (9%), and Rajasthan (8%). The 
average loan amount of the existing portfolio is ₹0.8 million. The average contractual tenor of the 
loans is 18 years, but the weighted average life is 6.6 years because of prepayments, which is 
common in India. Shubham is rated A– on the domestic scale by ICRA and CRISIL.

11.  Business  strategy.  Shubham  has  continued  to  focus  on  the  low-income  informal 
segment since its founding. From FY2017 to FY2021, assets under management (AUM) grew by 
about 26% annually. It will continue to focus on the self-employed and lower-income formal and 
informal salaried customers, penetrating deeper into its existing geographies. It plans to scale up 
its distribution networkand will continue to focus on home purchase loans and self-construction 
home loans, with a steady share of home equity loans, largely for small businesses. To support 
its growth plans, Shubham is planning to raise up to ₹6.0 billion of primary capital within FY2022. 
 
C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
 
Ownership. As of the end of FY2021, Shubham’s promoters, Sanjay Chaturvedi and Rupa Basu, 
own 11.6% of the company. Other institutional investors include Premji Invest (42.7%), Helion 
Venture Partners (14.3%), Elevar Equity (14.3%), and Motilal Oswal (12.8%).21 As part of the 
current equity raise, Elevar Equity, which had invested in 2011, is expected to fully exit while 
Motilal Oswal, which invested in 2015, is expected to partially sell its equity stake.  
 
12.  Governance structure. Shubham’s board of directors has 11 members, including 4 
independent directors, 5 nominee directors (2 representing Premji Invest and 1 each representing 
the other institutional investors), and the 2 cofounders. The chair of the board, Vinod Rai, is an 
independent director. Rai was the former comptroller and auditor general of India. The board 
members have experience across the financial services sector, consumer businesses in retail 
commercial banks, impact investing, and government entities. The audit committee and the risk 
management committee each has an independent chair, whereas the remuneration committee 
has a nonexecutive chair. Shubham’s statutory auditor is S.R. Batliboi & Associates, an affiliate 
of Ernst & Young.  
 
13.  Management. Shubham’s cofounder and chief executive officer, Sanjay Chaturvedi, has 
more than 30 years of experience in retail financial services working for Citibank, HSBC, and GE 
Consumer Finance. The cofounder and executive director, Rupa Basu, has more than 23 years 
of experience in risk management, credit underwriting, and compliance, working with companies 
such as the India Mortgage Guarantee Corporation, Citibank, Standard Chartered Bank, and 
PricewaterhouseCoopers. Other key management positions are held by seasoned professionals, 
including Rajesh Sood, chief operating officer, and Sanjeev Mittal, chief business officer, each of 
whom has more than 20 years of experience in the finance industry. 
 
14.  Risk management. Shubham has a comprehensive risk management policy in place, 
covering credit, operational, market, and enterprise risk management overseen by the risk 
management committee. The risk management department consists of three functional units: (i) 
a credit policy and risk control, (ii) an analytics and decision management, and (iii) a risk 
containment unit.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
15.  ADB will make an equity investment of up to $35 million (Indian rupee equivalent) in 
compulsorily convertible preference shares and equity shares issued by Shubham. ADB will 
invest an initial tranche of up to $27 million (Indian rupee equivalent) 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  Use of proceeds. ADB’s equity investment will provide growth capital to Shubham and 
support its operations to provide affordable housing to the EWS and LIG segments and home 
equity loans for small businesses in primarily semi- and peri-urban areas of India. 
 
17.  Reporting  arrangements.  ADB  will  monitor  the  project  throughout  its  duration.23 
Shubham will report at regular intervals with (i) quarterly unaudited financial statements, (ii) 
annual audited financial statements, (iii) annual development effectiveness indicators agreed 
between ADB and Shubham, (iv) annual reports on safeguards and social protection compliance, 
and (v) annual progress reports on the implementation of the GAP. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
18.  Access to housing for underserved segments. India’s mortgage markets are still 
underdeveloped and lower-income segments, in particular, lack access to mortgage finance 
(paras. 6–7). Housing is also a strong contributor to employment. According to an ADB study, ₹10 
million invested in construction creates 22,000 unskilled, 23,000 skilled and semi-skilled, and 
9,000 managerial and technical person workdays in India.24 As up to 40% of Indian homes in 
urban areas are nonpermanent, the project target extends access to affordable permanent quality 
housing to lower-income households. This segment accounts for about 75% of Shubham’s 
portfolio and thus represents an inclusive business model. 
 
19.  Providing growth capital and attracting private capital. ADB will be Shubham’s first 
multilateral development bank partner and will help facilitate an up to ₹6.0 billion primary capital 
raise from new investors.  
 
20.  Adherence to  market-leading  standards  and improved  gender  responsiveness. 
Shubham’s adherence to high corporate governance standards and its adoption of market-leading 
risk management, social, and environmental standards will be improved by ADB’s nomination of 
a director to the company’s board. The investment will also support Shubham’s expansion of its 
lending and financial inclusion services to women. The company is committed to improving 
gender responsiveness in its operations through the implementation of a GAP, which notably 
includes more gender-inclusive human resources management practices.25

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
21.  Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: access to housing finance for 
lower-income households increased (a PMAY initiative) (footnote 3). 
 
22.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: availability of affordable housing 
financing for the lower-income households, and particularly for women, improved.  
 
23.  Outputs. The project will have the following outputs: (i) capacity of Shubham to serve 
lower income households improved, (ii) capacity to serve women borrowers improved, (iii) 
capacity  to  cater  to  lagging  states  of  India  improved,  (iv)  gender  equality  in  employment 
opportunities improved, and (v) gender responsiveness in the work environment enhanced. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
24.  The project will contribute to the following operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030: 
(i) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, (ii) accelerating progress in gender 
equality, and (iii) making cities more livable.26 According to ADB’s country partnership strategy for 
India, 2018–2022, ADB’s nonsovereign operations will continue to support the finance sector.27 
The project will also support access to affordable housing in lagging states, in line with the PMAY 
initiative. Lastly, the project is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 2: 
Accelerating Progress in Gender Equality, 2019–2024.28 
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
25.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009).29 The investment is categorized FI for environment, and FI-C for involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples based on the current and likely portfolio impacts and risks. 
Activities categorized A for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples; or B 
for involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples will be excluded from financing. 
 
26.  Based on Shubham’s current and expected future loans portfolio, loan activities are not 
anticipated to result in significant environmental or social impacts. However, Shubham is testing 
a new product focused on small and medium-sized residential building construction loans (of a 
maximum loan value up to $400,000 equivalent).  Such loans will be screened and categorized 
for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. Borrowers will also need to 
comply with national laws and regulations through loan agreements. Shubham will (i) apply ADB's 
prohibited investment activities list; (ii) exclude activities with category A environment impacts and 
activities categorized as A and B on involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples impacts;

27.  Shubham will develop a detailed environmental and social management system (ESMS) 
aligned  with  its  policies  and  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  requirements  for  financial 
institutions, commensurate to the impacts and risks associated with its loan products. Shubham 
has agreed to develop the ESMS prior to first disbursement. Shubham will also ensure that staff 
are trained to implement the ESMS and address gaps identified during ADB’s due diligence. 30 
 
28.  Environmental and social safeguards. Based on its current portfolio, almost all of 
Shubham’s loans fall within the environment category C classification, wherein its existing loans 
are likely to have minimal environmental impacts. The climate change impact from the project is 
expected to be low because of the nature and scale of current and anticipated future loan products 
offered by the company. No land acquisition, physical or economic displacement, or impact on 
indigenous peoples’ communities are expected since the housing loans will be provided to 
individuals who have purchased the property or are voluntarily making improvements to their 
dwellings. During housing construction, standard risks such as health and safety of workers and 
the community are likely to occur. Impacts associated with noise, dust, traffic, erosion, and the 
storage and disposal of hazardous and/or nonhazardous waste will be identified and mitigated. 
Given the small-scale of construction, these issues can be adequately managed and mitigated 
through national law and the implementation of an effective ESMS. 
29.  The head of human resources is responsible for the implementation of the environmental 
and social management policy and the delivery of related training to staff. Currently, technical 
valuation training includes aspects such as safe design and construction, natural hazard risk, 
impacts on communities, and pollution and groundwater impacts. Shubham will upskill and train 
its existing staff to enable the effective implementation of the ESMS. The ESMS will require 
Shubham to report on training delivered, and on compliance of loans with environmental and 
social requirements, in particular potential category B loans (such as large construction loans). 
 
30.  Labor and social protection.  Shubham has in place a robust policy and mechanism to 
address sexual harassment in compliance with the requirements of the Sexual Harassment of 
Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013; no complaints have 
been received since the policy and related training were implemented. Its FY2020 annual report 
indicated that there were no material developments related to human resources and/or industrial 
relations adversely affecting the company’s business during FY2020. Shubham will comply with 
national labor laws and, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy, will take measures to 
comply with the internationally recognized core labor standards. Shubham will report on its 
compliance with such laws. Information disclosure will follow ADB requirements.31 
 
31.  Gender equity as a theme. Gender analysis conducted during due diligence indicated 
that Shubham follows an underwriting approach aimed to better understand women’s credit 
behaviors and their involvement in a borrower’s household. However, it applies a gender-neutral 
corporate approach, leading to gender gaps in its staffing and operations. Shubham is committed 
to expand its outreach and develop new tailored products for female customers; it plans to 
address corporate gender gaps through the introduction of gender measures. Following ADB’s

8 
Policy on Gender and Development (1998),32 key features of the GAP include (i) increasing the 
volume of housing and home equity loans outstanding to women; (ii) increasing disbursements 
from its women-specific products; (iii) piloting a financial literacy session covering budgeting, 
financial and business planning with primary women borrowers; (iv) introducing annual training 
for  women  staff  tailored  to  their  career  development  needs;  (v)  adopting  gender-sensitive 
recruitment practices to strengthen gender equality in hiring and selection processes; and (vi) 
establishing  a  company-wide  women’s  network  or  mentorship  program  to  support  women 
employees and build women’s leadership in the workplace. Shubham will submit periodic reports 
on implementation of its gender action plan to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
32.  Shubham was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED  
 
D.  Assurances 
 
33.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter), 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of India 
has no objection to the proposed assistance to Shubham.33 ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $35,000,000 (in Indian rupee equivalent) from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources  in  Shubham  Housing  Development  Finance  Company  Limited  for  the  Shubham 
Supporting Housing Finance in Semi- and Peri-Urban Areas Project in India, with such terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be 
reported to the Board.

metadata.Subject:
The equity investment of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provides growth capital to Shubham to support the expansion of its operations to provide critically needed affordable housing finance and home equity loans, primarily to economically weaker sections (EWS) and low-income groups (LIG) in semi- and peri-urban areas.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated October 2021 is provided for the ADB project 55099-001 in India.
